message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Isomorphism Checking in GROOVE
Paper Abstract: In this paper we show how isomorphism checking can be used as an effective technique for symmetry reduction in graph-based state spaces, despite the inherent complexity of the isomorphism problem. In particular, we show how one can use /element-based graph certificate mappings/ to help in recognising non-isomorphic graphs. These are mappings that assign to all elements (edges and nodes) of a given graph a number that is invariant under isomorphism, in the sense that any isomorphism between graphs is sure to preserve this number. The individual element certificates of a graph give rise to a certificate for the entire graph, which can be used as a hash key for the graph; hence, this yields a heuristic to decide whether a graph has an isomorphic representative in a previously computed set of graphs. We report some experiments that show the viability of this method.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Hash Function Overview

A hash function is a computational algorithm that serves several important purposes in computer science and cryptography.

### Basic Definition and Purpose

In a hash table, a hash function takes a key as an input, which is associated with a datum or record and used to identify it to the data storage and retrieval application.(no content)A hash function may be considered to perform three functions: convert variable-length keys into fixed-length (usually machine-word-length or less) values, scramble the bits of the key so that the resulting values are uniformly distributed over the keyspace, and map the key values into ones less than or equal to the size of the table.

### Key Properties

A good hash function satisfies two basic properties: it should be very fast to compute, and it should minimize duplication of output values (collisions).

### Types of Hash Functions

There are two main categories:

1. **Non-Cryptographic Hash Functions**: The non-cryptographic hash functions (NCHFs) are hash functions intended for applications that do not need the rigorous security requirements of the cryptographic hash functions (e.g., preimage resistance) and therefore can be faster and less resource-intensive.(no content)Among the typical uses of non-cryptographic hash functions are bloom filters, hash tables, and count sketches.

2. **Cryptographic Hash Functions**: Most cryptographic hash functions are designed to take a string of any length as input and produce a fixed-length hash value.(no content)Cryptographic hash functions are used in cybersecurity to secure sensitive data such as passwords.

### Special Case: Perfect Hash Functions

In computer science, a perfect hash function h for a set S is a hash function that maps distinct elements in S to a set of m integers, with no collisions.

Web search results for query: "graph isomorphism"

Links: [{"title":"Graph isomorphism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_isomorphism"},{"title":"Graph isomorphism problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_isomorphism_problem"},{"title":"Weisfeiler Leman graph isomorphism test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weisfeiler_Leman_graph_isomorphism_test"},{"title":"Talk:Graph isomorphism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Graph_isomorphism"},{"title":"Graph homomorphism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_homomorphism"},{"title":"Fractional graph isomorphism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_graph_isomorphism"},{"title":"Subgraph isomorphism problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subgraph_isomorphism_problem"},{"title":"Talk:Graph isomorphism/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Graph_isomorphism/Archive_1?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Induced subgraph isomorphism problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Induced_subgraph_isomorphism_problem"},{"title":"Graph automorphism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_automorphism"}]

Here are the search results for "graph isomorphism":

## Overview

Graph isomorphism captures the notion that some objects have "the same structure" if one ignores individual distinctions of "atomic" components of objects. Two graphs are isomorphic if there is a structure-preserving correspondence between them.

## The Graph Isomorphism Problem

The computational problem of determining whether two finite graphs are isomorphic is called the graph isomorphism problem. The graph isomorphism problem is one of few standard problems in computational complexity theory belonging to NP, but not known to belong to either of its well-known subsets: P and NP-complete. The problem is not known to be solvable in polynomial time nor to be NP-complete, and therefore may be in the computational complexity class NP-intermediate.

## Practical Applications

Practical applications include primarily cheminformatics, mathematical chemistry (identification of chemical compounds), and electronic design automation (verification of equivalence of various representations of the design of an electronic circuit).

## Algorithms

The Weisfeiler Leman graph isomorphism test can be used to heuristically test for graph isomorphism. If the test fails the two input graphs are guaranteed to be non-isomorphic. If the test succeeds the graphs may or may not be isomorphic. Another well-known algorithm for graph isomorphism is the vf2 algorithm, which is a depth-first search algorithm that tries to build an isomorphism between two graphs incrementally.

## Graph Theory Overview

Graph theory is the study of graphs, which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects in mathematics and computer science.(no content)A graph is made up of vertices (also called nodes or points) which are connected by edges (also called arcs, links or lines).

### Historical Background

The paper written by Leonhard Euler on the Seven Bridges of Königsberg and published in 1736 is regarded as the first paper in the history of graph theory.

### Applications

Graph theory has numerous practical applications across various fields:

- **Chemistry and Physics**: In chemistry a graph makes a natural model for a molecule, where vertices represent atoms and edges bonds.
- **Linguistics**: Graph-theoretic methods have proven particularly useful in linguistics, since natural language often lends itself well to discrete structure.
- **Neuroscience**: In computational neuroscience graphs can be used to represent functional connections between brain areas that interact to give rise to various cognitive processes.
- **Sociology**: Graph theory is widely used in sociology as a way to measure actors' prestige or to explore rumor spreading through social network analysis.
- **Navigation**: Weighted graphs are commonly used to program GPS's and travel-planning search engines that compare flight times and costs.

### Key Concepts

A graph structure can be extended by assigning a weight to each edge, and weighted graphs are used to represent structures in which pairwise connections have some numerical values.

- **Linguistics**: Graph-theoretic methods have proven particularly useful in linguistics, since natural language often lends itself well to discrete structure.
- **Neuroscience**: In computational neuroscience graphs can be used to represent functional connections between brain areas that interact to give rise to various cognitive processes.
- **Sociology**: Graph theory is widely used in sociology as a way to measure actors' prestige or to explore rumor spreading through social network analysis.
- **Navigation**: Weighted graphs are commonly used to program GPS's and travel-planning search engines that compare flight times and costs.

### Key Concepts

A graph structure can be extended by assigning a weight to each edge, and weighted graphs are used to represent structures in which pairwise connections have some numerical values.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about **symmetry reduction**:

## Definition

When a system's dynamics is unchanged by the action of a group, that symmetry can be removed by taking a quotient of the group action. This is symmetry reduction.

## Applications

Symmetry reduction has several important applications:

### In Differential Equations
Symmetry reduction is used to reduce systems of differential equations, finding equivalent systems of differential equations of simpler form.(no content)The order of an ordinary differential equation can be reduced by one if it is invariant under one-parameter Lie group of point transformations.

### In Computational Problems
The solution time of a combinatorial problem can be reduced by adding new constraints, referred as symmetry breaking constraints, such that some of the symmetric solutions are eliminated from the search space while preserving the existence of at least one solution.

### Mathematical Framework
Symmetry reduction works by exploiting the underlying structure of systems that remain unchanged under certain transformations. This approach, developed substantially by Sophus Lie in the context of differential equations, has become a powerful mathematical technique for simplifying complex systems across many areas of science and engineering.

Web search results for query: "state space"

Links: [{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"},{"title":"State space (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_(computer_science)"},{"title":"State-space search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_search"},{"title":"Quantum state space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_(physics)"},{"title":"State/Space theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State/Space_theory"},{"title":"State-space planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_planning"},{"title":"State space enumeration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_enumeration"},{"title":"State space (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"State variable - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_variable"},{"title":"Talk:State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:State_space_(controls)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of state space:

## Overview

State space is a concept used across multiple disciplines with different applications:

### Control Engineering and Systems
In control engineering and system identification, a state-space representation is a mathematical model of a physical system that uses state variables to track how inputs shape system behavior over time through first-order differential equations or difference equations.(no content)State-space models are applied in fields such as economics, statistics, computer science, electrical engineering, and neuroscience.

### Computer Science
In computer science, a state space is a discrete space representing the set of all possible configurations of a system, which is a useful abstraction for reasoning about the behavior of a given system and is widely used in the fields of artificial intelligence and game theory.(no content)State spaces can be either infinite or finite, and discrete or continuous.

### State-Space Search
State-space search is a process used in the field of computer science, including artificial intelligence (AI), in which successive configurations or states of an instance are considered, with the intention of finding a goal state with the desired property.

### Physics
In physics, a quantum state space is an abstract space in which different "positions" represent not literal locations, but rather quantum states of some physical system.

The concept of state space is fundamental for modeling and understanding complex systems across many scientific and engineering disciplines.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

- **5 triples** extracted and validated

- Multiple **existing methods and concepts** are leveraged (graph isomorphism, state spaces, hash functions)

3. **State space (computer science)** (concept) - The domain where the technique is applied
4. **Hash function** (method) - Used for certificate-based graph identification
5. **Graph theory** (concept) - Mathematical foundation
